New Records: Quinton de Kock smashed the tournament’s highest individual score so far – and the ninth-biggest total in men’s World Cup history
Key Match Events: De Kock had announced he would quit one-day internationals after the World Cup in India and the opener appears determined to make his farewell a memorable one, racking up his third century of the tournament.
De Kock combined with Markram (60) in a 131-run stand to steady the innings.
He and Heinrich Klaasen then tore apart the Bangladesh attack, plundering 142 runs from just 87 balls.
De Kock duly brought up his third hundred in five matches at the tournament and went on to topple India’s Virat Kohli as the tournament’s leading run-scorer.
Klaasen belted 90 off 49 balls as South Africa plundered 144 runs from the last 10 overs to leave Bangladesh with a mountain to climb.
Marco Jansen dented the Bangladesh top order by removing Tanzid Hasan and Najmul Hossain Shanto with successive deliveries.
Post-Match Reflections: The Proteas have now won four of their five pool-stage games and sit second in the table.
Miscellaneous Highlights: South Africa were not as clinical against the tail though, allowing Bangladesh to run up 233 before bowling them out with 3.2 overs to spare.
Others: Aiden Markram, leading the side in the absence of the unwell Temba Bavuma, won the toss and elected to bat.
Mahmudullah offered resistance with a run-a-ball 111 but it was not enough to avert a heavy defeat.
